content: Acceptance test–driven development (ATDD) is a methodology focused on communication between business customers, developers, and testers. It incorporates practices from specification by example (SBE), behavior-driven development (BDD), and example-driven development (EDD). ATDD helps developers and testers understand customer needs before implementation, allowing for conversations in the customer's domain language.

The Association for Software Testing (AST) promotes the science and practice of software testing based on context-driven principles. Founded by Cem Kaner in 2004, AST's members include scholars, students, and practitioners. Objectives include fostering idea exchange, hosting conferences, promoting ethics, and supporting peer workshops in the field.

content: Basis path testing is a white box method in software engineering that analyzes the control-flow graph of a program to find linearly independent paths. It uses McCabe cyclomatic complexity to generate test cases for each path, ensuring complete branch coverage without covering all possible paths. While not covering all paths may be co

Bebugging, also known as fault seeding or error seeding, is a software engineering technique from the 1970s used to measure test coverage. Known bugs are randomly added to a program's source code, and the software tester must find them. The percentage of known bugs not found gives an indication of the remaining real bugs. The term was first mentioned in The Psychology of Computer Programming (1970) as a way to train, motivate, and evaluate programmers. This approach was borrowed from the SAGE system, where it was used to keep operators alert while watching radar screens. The technique has been refined over time, with early applications like Harlan Mills's fault seeding approach. Bebugging is a type of fault injection used to estimate the number of remaining faults in a software system.

A test bench is used to verify the correctness of a design or model, originally in electronic device testing. In software or hardware engineering, it is an environment where the product is tested with software and hardware tools. Changes may need to be made to the software to work with the test bench, but careful coding can ensure reversibility without introducing bugs. In digital design, a test bench refers to the test code that instantiates the device under test (DUT) and runs the test. It can also refer to an isolated, controlled environment similar to the production environment but not visible to the gene

content: Business Process Validation (BPV) is crucial for ensuring that end-to-end business processes function correctly to avoid disruptions that can impact revenue, reputation, and customer satisfaction. By identifying defects early, before new enterprise software is deployed, companies can minimize the cost of fixing issues. During BPV, business processes are checked using representative data to ensure that all business rules and transactions are working across all enterprise applications. BPV can be performed on a project basis for new software deployments, on a periodic basis for regular updates, or on a continuous basis for ongoing validation of processes and systems.

In software engineering, a test case specifies inputs, conditions, procedures, and expected results for a single test to achieve a testing objective. It ensures methodical testing rather than random. Test cases can be systematically built to cover the software being tested, allowing for consistent regression testing across different software versions.

Compatibility testing is essential for ensuring that software applications can function effectively in various computing environments. The ISO 25010 standard defines compatibility as the ability of a software system to exchange information with other systems using the same software and hardware. Co-existence refers to the product's ability to function efficiently alongside other products in the same environment, while interoperability is the ability of systems to exchange and use information. Research and literature on concurrency testing focuses on testing software and systems that use concurrent computing to understand their behavior and performance. This research dates back to the 1950s and has identified issues such as incorrect shared memory access and unexpected order sequences in message or thread execution. Other challenges include resource contention, scheduling, deadlock avoidance, priority inv

Conformance testing, also known as compliance testing, determines if a process, product, or service meets specified requirements. Testing can be logical or physical, and may involve mathematical or chemical criteria. Beyond basic conformance, efficiency, interoperability, and other factors may be considered. Testing can be done by the producer, user, or accredited organization, leading to certification. Manufacturers rely on certification to assure quality to customers and maintain competitiveness. Other conformance testing activities include surveillance, inspection, auditing, certification, and accreditation.

content: Continuous testing is the practice of running automated tests throughout the software delivery process to quickly identify any business risks in a potential release. Originally aimed at reducing feedback wait times for developers, it now encompasses testing from basic requirements to overall business objectives

In engineering, a corner case is a problem that occurs when multiple environmental factors are at extreme levels outside normal operating parameters. For example, a loudspeaker may distort audio at maximum volume, bass, and in high humidity. Investigating corner cases is crucial for engineers to understand and mitigate potential issues. These cases are difficult to reproduce and test, as they require maximal configurations in multiple dimensions. Expert users often discover corner case anomalies and errors. The term comes from the "flight envelope" metaphor, with corner cases involving extreme values for multiple variables, pushing users to the corner of a multidimensional space.

Data-driven testing (DDT) is a methodology for software testing where test inputs and outputs are described in a table, instead of hard-coding them. Testers provide inputs from a table row and expect corresponding outputs. The table usually includes values for boundary or partition input spaces. Test configuration is "read" fro
A DD-path is a path between two decisions in a program's flow graph. New versions also include the decisions themselves in their

Design predicates, created by Thomas McCabe, quantify software integration complexity. Each type has a complexity rating, which can be combined for code using multiple predicates. The integration complexity plus one determines the maximum test cases needed. Test engineers can reduce this by covering all design predicates, but some combinations may b
In Linux, FreeBSD, NetBSD, /dev/full is a special file always returning ENOSPC on writing and an infinite number of zero bytes on reading, ideal for testing programs handling "disk full" errors.

Development testing comprises various defect prevention and detection strategies to minimize risks, time, and costs in software development. It may involve static code analysis, metrics analysis, peer code reviews, unit testing, code coverage analysis
Documentation testing is a type of non-functional testing that ensures the accuracy of user manuals and system guides. It verifies if system c

The domain-to-range ratio (DRR) is a mathematical ratio that compares the number of inputs to outputs in a logical function or software component. It is calculated as the cardinality of the input set (domain) divided by the cardinality of the output set (range). DRR can help assess the risk of overlooking errors during out

A dry run, or practice run, is a crucial software testing process to ensure system functionality and prevent failure. For instance, rsync offers a "dry-run" option for users to validate command-line arguments and simulate data transfer without actually copying it. In acceptance procedures like factory acceptance testing, a "dry

Dynamic program analysis involves analyzing software by executing the program, unlike static analysis. It can focus on behavior, test coverage, performance, and security. To be effective, the program needs to be executed with diverse test inputs to cover all possible scenarios. Tools l
Dynamic testing involves examining the runtime response of a software system to specific inputs. Tests can be done manually or automated, including unit testing, integration testing

An edge case is a problem that occurs at the extreme operating parameters, like distortion at maximum volume in a stereo speaker. It can be expected or unexpected, caused by unpredictable user behavior, evolving use cases, limited test coverage, product complexity, resource limitations, or other external factors. Examples include a long username overflowing in an app and a booking system failing on a leap day. Addressing edge cases is crucial in engineering to prevent failures that were unforeseen during design. Good engineering standards often include information about edge cases to avoid overlooking or underestimating them.

Elementary comparison testing (ECT) is a white-box, control-flow methodology for detailed testing of complex software. It involves testing software code or pseudocode to ensure proper handling of all decision outcomes. Coverage of all independent and isolated conditions is achieved through modified condition/decision coverage (MC/DC). Isolated conditions

Exploratory testing, coined by Cem Kaner in 1984, is an approach to software testing focused on simultaneous learning, test design, and execution. It emphasizes the tester's freedom and responsibility to optimize work quality through continuous learning, design, execution, and result interpretation. Testers generate new tests based on experience and creativity while testing the software. It is considered a versatile test approach that can be applied to any technique at any stage of development. The key to effective exploratory testing is the cogn

Fault injection is a testing technique in computer science that involves stressing computing systems in unusual ways to understand how they behave. This can be done using physical, software-based, or hybrid means. Physical fault injections involve applying high voltages, extreme temperatures, and electromagnetic pulses to electronic components, causing mis-executions and data corruption.

In software testing, fault injection is used to improve test coverage by introducing faults to code paths, particularly error handling paths. It is commonly used with stress testing and is considered essential for developing robust software. Robustness testing, also known as fuzzing, is a type of fault injection used to test communication interfaces for vulnerabilities.

The propagation of a fault to an observable failure follows a well-defined cycle. When a fa

Functional testing in software development verifies whether software matches its design, focusing on compliance with functional requirements. It is a black-box approach, ignoring internal program structure. This testing is not limited to testing the code of a single function but tests slices of functionality of the whole system. Sometimes, it is part of the quality assurance process and differs from acceptance testing, which validates a program against published user or system requi

content: Fuzzing is an automated software testing technique that involves providing invalid or random data to a program to monitor for exceptions. It is effective for testing programs with structured inputs, generating inputs that are "valid enough" to not be rejected but "invalid enough" to expose corner cases. Fuzzing code that handles input crossing a trust boundary is crucial for security, prioritizing testing where any user can upload a file over privileged user-accessible configuration files.

content: Keyword-driven testing, or action word based testing, is a versatile software testing approach for manual and automated testing. It separates the documentation of test cases from how they are executed, dividing the process into design and execution stages. The design stage includes requirement and data ana

Lightweight software test automation involves creating and using short and simple computer programs called lightweight test harnesses to test a software system. These harnesses are usually implemented with languages like Java, Perl, Visual Basic .NET, and C#. They are typically four pages of code or less and take four hours or less to write. This approach is often associated with Agile software development.

The primary alternatives to lightweight software test automation are commercial test automation frameworks, Open Source test automation frameworks, and heavyweight test automation. The main disadvantage of lightweight test automation is manageability, as it can overwhelm a test effort with numerous harness programs and files. However, it is less expensive and more flexible than commercial frameworks, more stable than Open Source frameworks, and quicker to implement and modify than heavyweight automation. It is typically used to complement, not replace, these alternatives.

Mauve is a free software test suite for Java class libraries. It is developed by members of Kaffe, GNU Classpath, GCJ, and other projects. Unlike JUnit, Mauve is designed to run on experimental Java virtual machines and does not discover testing methods by name. It can also test use

Metamorphic testing (MT) is a property-based software testing technique that addresses the test oracle problem and test case generation problem. It uses metamorphic relations (MRs), which are necessary properties of the software's functionality and involve multiple executions. For example, MT can be applied to a program implementing sin x correct to 100 significant figures, with the MR "sin(π − x) = sin x". This allows for follow-up test cases to verify the consistency of the program's output. MT is not limited to numerical inputs or equality relations; it has been applied to web services, computer graphics, embedded systems, and more. MT can be applied independently or combined with other software analysis techniques. Google acquired GraphicsFuzz to apply MT to graphics device drivers for Android smartphones in 2018.

Metasploit Project, owned by Rapid7, is a computer security project focused on vulnerability information, penetration testing, and IDS signature development. Its popular sub-project, the open-source Metasploit Framework, is a tool for executing exploit code on remote targets. Other sub-projects include Opcode Database and anti-forens
MockServer is an open source mocking framework for HTTP and HTTPS under the Apache License. It simplifies integration testing by mocking web services, decoupling developmen

Model-based testing is an application of model-based design for software and system testing. It uses models to represent the behavior of a system under test (SUT) and testing strategies. Test cases derived from these models are known as abstract test suites, which cannot be directly executed against the SUT. Executable test suites need to be derived from the abstract test suites, either by mapping abstract test cases to concrete test cases or by generating executable test suites directly from the models. Test derivation is usually experimental and heuristic-based, with parameters consolidated into a package known as "test requirements" or "test purpose". Model-based testing is considered a form of black-box testing. The field of model-based testing for complex software systems is still evolving.

Monkey testing is a software testing methodology where users provide random inputs to the application or system to check for crashes. This technique is often implemented as random, automated unit tests. The name "monkey" may come from the infinite monkey theorem or from a classic Mac OS application called "The Monkey." Monkey Testing is also a standard stress testing tool in Android Studio.

Established in 2007, they offer open source projects, security courses, ExploitDB, and Kali Linux. Founded by Mati Aharoni, OffSec employs experienced security professionals and offers tra
Pair testing involves two team members working on one keyboard to test software. One tester conducts tests while the other reviews. It can involve a tester with a developer, busines

Parameter validation in computer software is automated processing within a module to ensure the accuracy of parameters. Common for over 30 years, best practices exist to improve handling. It can also help preven

Partial concurrent thinking aloud (PCTA) is a method developed by Stefano Federici and Simone Borsci at the University of Rome "La Sapienza" for usability testing with screen reader users. It combines elements of both concurrent and retrospective thinking aloud protocols to gather more pertinent data from blind users. PCTA allows for a more direct and relevant assessment of usability compared to traditional thinking aloud methods, which can be hindered by structural interference for blind users. This technique can be utilized in both summative and formative usability evaluations with mixed panels of users to capture a broader range of problems and strategies used by disabled individuals during navigation.

A penetration test (pentest) is an authorized simulated cyberattack on a computer system to evaluate security, not to be confused with a vulnerability assessment. It identifies weaknesses and strengths, enabling a full risk assessment. The target may be white box (background provided) or black box (limited information). Results are reported to the system owner, assessing potential impacts and suggesting countermeasures. Penetration testing supports risk assessments and is required by certain standards. Several standard frameworks and methodologies exist for conducting penetration tests. Flaw hypothesis methodology is a technique for predicting and prioritizing flaws in a software system. There are different types of penetration testing, including network, wireless, web application, social engineering, and remediation verification.
A test plan outlines objectives, resources, and processes for a test session. It provides a detailed workflow

A playtest is a crucial process for game designers to identify bugs and design flaws before releasing a new game to market. It can be open to anyone or closed to internal testers, and may also involve beta testing just before the product launch. Playtesters are individuals who participate in the testing process and may be required to sign non-disclosure agreements to protect the designer's copyrights. The term is also used in unofficial situations for private game testing or to test new strategies or game mechanics. Overall, playtesting is an essential part of the game development process.

Portability testing evaluates how easily a software component can be transferred between different environments. Test results measure integration ease compared to non-functional portability requirements. Correctness levels are based on the cost to adapt the software to a new environment versus redevelopment costs.

Process validation involves analyzing data from product design and manufacturing to ensure consistent output quality. Regulatory agencies like EMA and FDA have guidelines for this. The goal is to ensure inputs lead to high-quality outputs. It is an ongoing process that must be adjusted based on manufacturing feedback. To achieve end-to-end validation, three steps are involved: process design, process qualification, and continued pr

Mutation testing, also known as mutation analysis, is a method used to improve software testing by creating modified versions of a program called mutants. The goal is to detect and reject mutants by causing differences in behavior from the original program, a process known as "killing the mutant." Test suites are evaluated based on the percentage of mutants they can successfully eliminate. By using predefined mutation operators, testers can mimic common programming errors or identify areas where tests may be lacking. This technique helps devel

Pseudolocalization is a software testing method that involves replacing text with altered versions of the original language to test internationalization. This method helps identify issues related to text length, language direction, interface compatibility, and more. For example, "Account Settings" may be displayed as "!!! Àççôûñţ Šéţţîñĝš !!!"

在软件工程的背景下，软件质量指的是两个相关但不同的概念：功能质量和结构质量。

功能质量反映了软件与给定设计的一致性，基于功能需求或规格，也可以描述为软件在市场上的竞争性和适用性。它是正确的软件生产程度。

结构质量则指的是软件如何满足支持功能需求的非功能性要求，如健壮性或可维护性。它与软件是否按需工作的程度有很大关联。

许多结构质量的方面只能通过静态的软件内部结构分析来评估，也可以通过单元级别和系统级别的测试来评估。如OMG的关于软件架构的原则的论文所述。

一些结构质量，例如可用性，只能通过动态测试来评估，而可靠性可能不仅涉及软件本身，还涉及底层硬件。

功能质量通常是动态评估、也可能通过静态测试进行评估。ISO 9126 和ISO/IEC 25000 标准提供了对软件质量管理的结构和术语的衡量。

软件质量测量从更直观的视角提供了软件质量地图、信息可视化的概念和技术。软件质量对软件项目的发布阶段也起着重要作用。特别是发布流程和配置管理是整个软件工程流程的重要组成部分。

content: Random testing is a black-box technique that tests programs using random, independent inputs. Outputs are compared to specifications to determine pass or fail. If specifications are absent, language exceptions are used to detect faults.

Real-time testing is crucial for real-time computer systems with strict timing constraints and deterministic behavior. Software testing is necessary to detect and correct bugs in computer software, ensuring error-free functionality. Conventional testing methods may not guarantee accurate results for real-time systems, making real-time testing essential to meet timing constraints and

Recovery testing is a crucial part of software testing, focusing on how well an application can bounce back from crashes and hardware failures. It involves deliberately causing failures to ensure the recovery process functions properly. This testing is not the same as reliability testing, which identifies when a failure occurs. Recovery testing evaluates how quickly and effectively the application can recover from various issues such as crashes and hardware failures. It involves simulating failure scenarios and testing failover mec

Regression testing involves re-running functional and non-functional tests to ensure that software still works after a change, preventing regressions. Changes like bug fixes, enhancements, and hardware substitutions may trigger regression testing. Robustness testing is a quality assurance method that tests software's ability to function correctly in the presence of invalid inputs or stressful conditions. The term was first used by the Ballista project at Carnegie Mellon University to test operating systems for dependability. It was later used by researchers in the PROTOS project for software security testing. Fuzzing, commonly used for non-intelligent robustness testing, has also been expanded to include model-based testing. ANSI

The roofline model assesses performance of compute kernels or applications on different processor architectures by highlighting hardware limitations and optimization priorities. It combines locality, bandwidth, and parallelization paradigms into a single figure, providing insights on implementation and inherent performance limitations. By plotting floating-point performance against machine peak performance and bandwidth, the model establishes a performance bound with platform-specific ceilings based on memory bandwidth and processor peak performance.

Runtime predictive analysis is a technique in computer science that uses a runtime monitor to detect property violations in program executions based on observed runs. It is commonly used to identify concurrency errors, like data races, in concurrent programs. The analysis is performed on an abstract model extracted online from the observed execution, al

A sanity test is a basic, quick evaluation to check if a claim or calculation is possible. It ensures rationality but does not catch all errors. For example, in arithmetic, checking if the sum of digits is divisible by 9 when multiplying by 9 is a sanity test. In computer science, it is a brief check of functionality before more thorough testing. This helps evaluate basic function quickly and discover potential errors.

It gives development and QA teams access to needed dependent system components for testing, even when the live components are unavailable. This allows testing and development to proceed without accessing the actual components. Service virtualization is distinct from mocking and is recognized as a valu

Session-based testing, developed by Jonathan and James Marcus Bach in 2000, combines accountability and exploratory testing for rapid defect discovery. It allows for creative on-the-fly test design, management control, and metrics reporting. This method can be used with scenario testing and is beneficial for immature test processes,

Smoke testing, also known as confidence or sanity testing, is a preliminary test to reveal simple failures that may reject a software release. It covers important functionality to assess if main functions work correctly, such as determining if a program runs or if the user interface opens. The aim is to quickly identify severe issues that would make further testing unnecessary. These tests are run quickly for faster feedback. Industry best practices include frequent reintegration with smoke testing and triggering Continuous Integration builds with every commit to catch regressions early. Microsoft claims smoke testing is cost-effective for identifying and fixing defects. It can be done manually or with automated tools, and can be functional or unit tests. Functional tests exercise the program with various inputs, while unit tests test individual functions, subroutines, or object methods. Unit tests can be implemented within the code or as a separate driver layer.

Software testability refers to how easily a software artifact can be tested in a given context. When a software artifact has high testability, it is easier to find faults through testing. Testability is determined by the existence of a verification function that validates the output of the system given specific inputs. 

Some software systems may be untestable initially, but can become testable with the right information or resources. Testability is influenced by the relationship between the software being tested and the goals, methods, and resources of the testing process. It is considered an intrinsic property of software, as it is closely related to key software qualities like encapsulation, coupling, cohesion, and redundancy.

Software with poor design qualities like weak cohesion, tight coupling, redundancy, and lack of encapsulation tends to have lower testability. This results in increased test effort and may even prevent certain parts of the software or

content: The Stream X-machine (SXM) is a computational model introduced by Gilbert Laycock in 1993. It is based on Samuel Eilenberg's X-machine, but is specifically designed for processing memory data types with input and output streams. Transitions in an SXM are labeled by functions that compute output values and update memory based on current memory and input. The SXM has led to a theory of complete functional testing, allowing for exhaustive testing of complex software systems and guaranteed proof of integration correctness. SXM is useful for modelling real-world phenomena and has applications in computational biology, software testing, and agent-based computational economics.

content: Stress testing in computing evaluates the limits of hardware or software by running resource-intensive tasks to determine system capabilities. It is used for scaling, reliability, and stability. Processes are run until the syste

Stress testing pushes software beyond normal limits to determine its robustness. It is crucial for critical software but is used for all types. The focus is on robustness, availability, and error handling under heavy loads, rather than correct behavior. System stress tests prioritize handling heavy loads, ensuring software doesn't crash under resource constraints or attacks.

A test suite, also known as a validation suite, is a collection of test cases used to test a software program's specified set of behaviors. It includes detailed instructions, system configurations, prerequisite states, and descriptions of following tests. Test suites are also referred to as test p

System integration testing (SIT) is the comprehensive testing of a complete system made up of multiple subsystem components. This can include hardware, software, and human-in-the-loop testing. SIT is performed on a larger integrated system after individual subsystems have been tested.

SIT involves assembling system parts in a logical and cost-effective way, checking system execution thoroughly, and ensuring full functional capability. It verifies that the system meets requirements and performs as expected by the customer or user.

In technology product development, SIT is crucial as it tests the entire system for the first time. Prior to SIT, subsystems have been tested to ensure they meet their requirements at the interface level.

content: BLEU is a language evaluation algorithm developed by IBM in 2001 to assess the quality of machine-translated text. It measures the similarity between a machine's output and human translations, with a higher score indicating better quality. BLEU compares translated sentences to a set of reference translations and averages the scores to estimate overall quality. The output is a number between 0 and 1, with higher values indicating more similarity to reference texts. While a score of 1 is rare, adding more reference translations can increase the BLEU score. Intelligibility and grammatical correctness are not considered in the evaluation.
Machine translation tries to convert text or speech betwee

The F-score, also known as F-measure, is used in statistical analysis of binary classification and information retrieval systems to measure predictive performance. It is calculated from precision and recall, which represent the accuracy and completeness of the test results. The F1 score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall, providing a balanced representation of both metrics. The more generic Fβ score allows for additional weighting of precision or recall. An F-score ranges from 0 to 1, with 1 indicating perfect precision an

METEOR is a machine translation evaluation metric based on harmonic mean of unigram precision and recall, with recall weighted higher. It incorporates stemming and synonymy matching, along with exact word matching, to address issues in BLEU metric. It aims for good correlation with human judgement at sentence level, unlike BLEU which focuses on corpus level. Results show METEOR achieving up to 0.964 correlation with human judgement at corpus level, compared to BLEU's 0.8

content: NIST evaluates machine-translated text quality based on the rareness of matched n-grams, unlike BLEU which gives equal weight to all n-grams. Named after NIST, it analyzes how informative an n-gram is, with rarer ones receiving more weight. This method also minimizes the impact of minor translation length variations on the final score.

P4 metric evaluates binary classifier performance using precision, recall, specificity, and NPV. It addresses criticisms of F1 metric and is an extension of it, calculated from TP, TN, FP, FN like other metrics.

Post-editing is the process of humans editing machine-generated translations to achieve a final acceptable product, and the person who does this is called a post-editor. It is linked to the concept of pre-editing, where the source text is modified before being translated by a machine. Post-editing involves correcting the machine translation to meet a negotiated level of quality. There are two levels of post-editing: light, which aims for simple understandability, and full, which also focuses on stylistic appropriateness. With advancements in machine translation, full post-editing is becoming an alternative to manual translation, and most

The bank attributed the problem to internal data processing errors, but there was speculation of a hack. Some transactions from April 27 to May 3, 2017, were doubled, but the bank reassured that clients would not lose money. content: A crash in computing occurs when a software application or operating system stops functioning properly and exits. A crash reporting service will report the crash to the developer(s) and may result in a kernel panic or fatal system error if the program is critical to the operating system. Most crashes are caused by software bugs, such as accessing invalid memory addresses, buffer overflow, or executing invalid machine instructions. The original software bug that caused the crash is often discovered through the debugging process. Some crashes can be exploited by malicious programs or hackers to execute arbitrary code or acquire inaccessible data. In early personal computers, crashes could also cause hardware damage by writing data to

Dead code refers to code that can never be executed at runtime or code that is executed but its result is never used. Removing dead code can improve efficiency by saving computation time and memory. However, removing dead code may also introduce unintended bugs if the code raises exceptions or affects global state. Compiler optimizations are cautious when removing dead code to avoid changing the program's output. Programmers can help the compiler by using static or inl

A dead store in programming is when a local variable is assigned a value but not used again, wasting processor time and memory. It can be detected and removed by an optimizing compiler. However, this optimization can cause security issues when intentionally overwriting data, such as removing a password fr

Deadlock in concurrent computing occurs when entities wait for each other to take action, such as sending a message or releasing a lock, leading to a standstill. This is common in multiprocessing, parallel computing, and distributed systems where locks are used to manage shared resources and process synchronization. In an operating system, deadlock happens when a process is stuck waiting for a resource held by another waiting process, creating a cycle of waiting. In a communications system, deadlocks are more likely due to signa

The earliest known video game Easter egg is in the 1973 game Moonlander, where players can encounter a McDonald's restaurant. content: Exception handling in computing and programming is the process of dealing with unexpected conditions during program execution. When an exception occurs, it disrupts the normal flow of execution and triggers a pre-defined exception handler. Exceptions are classified by different layers of a computer system, including CPU interrupts, OS signals, and language-defined exceptions. Each layer requires specific handling methods, but they can also interact with each other
In programming, exception handling involves mechanisms for dealing with unexpected conditions. These exceptions store information and are raised using a "throw" mechanism, shi

In telecommunications, a fault is an accidental condition that causes a functional unit to fail or a defect that leads to reproducible malfunctions. In power systems, a fault is an unintentional short circuit between conductors or between a conductor and ground, classified as symmetric or

Unlike bugs, glitches are often temporary and mysterious, caused by unexpected inputs. Some even humorously refer to glitches as "gremlins in the computer hardware". Despite being difficult to troubleshoot, glitches are part of all systems, including human organizations and nature.

content: A hang or freeze in computing occurs when a process or system stops responding to inputs, such as when the graphical user interface no longer responds to keyboard or mouse inputs. This can be caused by a variety of factors, including software or hardware defects, resource exhaustion, slow network, misconfiguration, and compatibility problems. Hangs can be temporary or permanent, requiring manual intervention or rebooting. It differs from a crash, which is immediate and unrelated to input responsiveness. Operating systems may provide means to forcibly terminate hung programs or automatically handle them, while severe hangs may require rebooting the machine.

content: A heap overflow is a type of buffer overflow that occurs in the dynamically allocated heap data area. It differs from stack-based overflows as it involves corrupting data on the heap, such as linked list pointers, to overwrite program functions. One common technique involves manipulating malloc metadata to exchange pointers and overwrite function pointers. For example, on older Linux versions, manipulating buffer metadata can lead to buffer merging and pointer overwriting. By setting certain values, one buffer can overwrite another's metadata and overwrite function pointers.

Software aging is the tendency for software to fail after running continuously or because of changing systems. Causes include software's inability to adapt to changing needs and errors introduced by patches. Rebooting or reinstalling can provide a temporary fix. Software rejuvenation is a proactive method to manage aging, using agents to prevent incidents. The phenomenon was first identified by David Parnas, who proposed ways to address it. Research has increased on the causes and effects of software aging, such as memory bloating and leaking, data corruption, and unreleased file-locks.

content: A stack buffer overflow occurs when a program writes to a memory address outside of the intended data structure, usually a fixed-length buffer. This can result in corruption of adjacent data on the stack, leading to program crashes or incorrect operation. Such overflow bugs are a type of buffer overflow issue, posing a potential security threat if exploited maliciously. Attackers can inject executable code into the program, gaining unauthorized access to the system, especially if the program has special privileges or interacts with untrusted data sources. Stack buffer overflow is a common method used by attackers to compromise computer systems.

content: Automated code review software checks for compliance with rules and best practices, aiding in bug and security issue detection. The process can be manual or automated, with tools providing warnings and assistance to correct issues. This is crucial for mastering software and contributes to Software Intelligence. Static code analysis tools help with automated code review, offering faster and more efficient reviews than manual methods. Integrated Development Environments like Eclipse and Visual Studio support plugins for code review. Some tools analyze software structures to aid in understanding, without predefined rules. They allow defining target architectures and ensuring software implementation aligns with these constraints.

subcategories: List of tools for static code analysis

content: Code review, also known as peer review, is a crucial software quality assurance activity where one or more individuals review a program's source code to ensure quality and identify defects. The reviewers, excluding the author, strive to improve code quality, find defects, facilitate knowledge transfer, foster a sense of collective responsibility, explore better solutions, and adhere to guidelines and standards. Code review differs from other QA techniques like static code analysis, self checks, testing, and pair programming, as it involves human reviewers identifying issues through manual inspection rather than automated tools or individual checks.

Code reviewing software helps find flaws in program source code, ensuring quality. It is divided into automated tools that check code against rules and visual browsers that aid in understanding software structure. Manual tools allow collaborative inspection and discussion of changes, storing the process history for reference.

Code coverage, also known as test coverage in software engineering, measures the percentage of a program's source code that is executed when running a specific test suite. Higher test coverage indicates more code is tested, reducing the likelihood of undiscovered bugs compared to low coverage programs. Various metrics can be used to calculate test coverage, such as the percentage of program subrou

Debug_new 是 C++ 中一种调试内存使用的技术，通过重载和/或重新定义 operator new 和 operator delete 来拦截内存分配和释放调用。通常会定义一个名为 DEBUG_NEW 的宏，使 new 变成类似 new(__FILE__, __LINE__) 来记录文件/行信息。Microsoft Visual C++ 在其 Microsoft Foundation Classes 中使用了这种技术。有一些方法可以扩展这种方法，避免在一些平台上使用宏重新定义的方式，但仍能显示文件/行信息。

这种方法有许多固有限制。它仅适用于 C++，无法捕捉 C 函数（如 malloc）的内存泄漏。然而，与一些更完整的内存调试器解决方案相比，它可能非常简单且非常快速。

content: Electric Fence, developed by Bruce Perens, is a memory debugger that helps programmers find common bugs like buffer overruns and use-after-free errors. By triggering a program crash when these errors occur, Electric Fence allows developers to pinpoint the cause of the issue. It allocates extra memory for each buffer, leading to increased memory requirements. It is recommended to use Electric Fence on smaller programs for debugging purposes only and not leave it linked to production code. This tool is freely available under the GNU General Public License.

content: Fit is an open-source tool for automated customer tests, integrating work of customers, analysts, testers, and developers. Customers provide software examples in tables saved as HTML. HTML5test.com is a web app that evaluates a browser's implementation of common web standards, including HTML5, Web SQL Database, SVG, and WebGL. Developed by Dutch programmer Niels Leenheer in 2010, the app assigns a score out of 555 points. The scoring system was revamped in 2013. Leenheer announced the discontinuation of the app in 2024 due to server issues. Third-party mirrors have since been set up. HTML5test.com evaluates Web storage, Geolocation API, HTML5-specific elements, and more, but does not assess other standards like CSS or ECMAScript. Acid3 is used for conformance testing in those areas. Acid3 and HTML5Test.com have different test scopes.

An instruction set simulator (ISS) is a simulation model that mimics the behavior of a mainframe or microprocessor by emulating instructions and maintaining internal variables representing the processor's registers. ISS is used for various purposes, including simulating future processors to enable software development without waiting for hardware production, simulating machine code for compatibility, executing machine code for testing and debugging, and improving simulation speed compared to cycle-accurate simulators. For example, the IBM 1401 was simulated on the IBM/360 using microcode emulation. ISS can be used to simulate processor cores in hardware design using Verilog for faster simulations using "PLI".

Developed in the late 1960s at IBM's Product Test Laboratory in New York, SIMMON was a software testing system for IBM's System/360 computers. It was presented at the 1968 IBM SimSymp symposium and served as a hypervisor for testing guest programs. Unlike the multi-VM support in CP-40, SIMMON focused on single virtual machine testing. It allowed for the inclusion of independent test tools and played an important role in software testing for many years.

SoapUI 可以测试 SOAP 和 REST Web 服务、JMS、AMF，以及进行任何 HTTP(S) 和 JDBC 调用。

content: The Book of Mozilla is an Easter egg found in web browsers like Netscape, Mozilla, and Firefox. It features apocalyptic-style passages when about:mozilla is entered in the browser. The eight official verses mention a fearsome "beast," likely representing Netscape's mascot, the fire-breathing lizard named Mozilla. While the verses remain mysterious, annotations for some verses can be found in the HTML source code of the Book of Mozilla page, providing some insight into their meanings. It is important to note that these annotations were written by individuals not directly involved in the Mozilla Foundation's decision-making process.

The cow level is a popular secret level in the Diablo series, first appearing in Diablo II as the "Moo Moo Farm". Players can access it by collecting specific items to open a portal. The level features armed anthropomorphic cows led by the "Cow King". Originating as a hoax in the original Diablo game, the cow level became a well-known urban legend in gaming. Developers embraced the joke by including Easter egg references in related games before officially introducing the level in Diablo II. The cow level's popularity led to similar levels in later Blizzard games and inspired imitations in other video games.

content: The leap year problem, also called the leap year bug, affects digital and non-digital data storage by resulting from errors in calculating leap years or manipulating dates witho

The 1900 problem involves misinterpreting years with only their last two digits, leading to confusion over whether they occurred before or after 1900. Unlike the Y2K issue, this problem dates back before electronic computers and has affected manual systems as well. The main issue is with people's ages, as many birth years were recorded with only two digits. This has led to cases of individuals over 100 being mistaken for young children or vice versa.

To address this problem, some measures were taken during the Y2K preparations, such as modifying national identification numbers. For example, Bulgaria's Uniform civil number includes a two-digit birth year, but a solution was imple

The Corrupted Blood incident occurred in World of Warcraft from September 13 to October 8, 2005, resulting in a virtual pandemic due to a programming error during a boss battle in the game region of Zul'Gurub. The debuff, Corrupted Blood, spread to player characters and animal companions, causing panic among players. Some provided aid, while others intentionally spread the disease. Blizzard ended the pandemic with a hard reset and later prevented companions from contracting it. The incident attracted attention from players and researchers, leading Blizzard to create intentional in-game pandemics in later expansions. Epidemiologists found MMORPGs useful in studying human responses to disease outbreaks.

content: Glitching is the act of exploiting flaws in video games to achieve unintended outcomes. Players known as glitchers may stumble upon glitches by chance or actively search for them. Some glitches are easy to perform, while others require advanced techniques or tools. Glitches can involve manipulating game mechanics or even writing custom code within the game. They can be achieved through user input or hardware manipulation. Some glitches are well-understood, while others remain mysterious. Glitching is used in speedrunning and competitive gaming to gain an advantage or understand a game's mechanics. However, in some cases, it is considered cheating, and competitions may ban certain glitches. Speedrunning communities often create categories that either allow or restrict the use of glitches, giving players the freedom to choose their preferred

BLEU is an algorithm that evaluates machine-translated text quality based on its similarity to human translations. Developed by IBM in 2001, BLEU is known for its high correlation with human judgments and affordability. Scores are calculated for individual segments by comparing them to a set of reference translations, providing an overall quality estimate. The output ranges from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating greater similarity to the reference texts. While a score of 1 is rare, adding more reference translations can improve the BLEU score by providing more matching opportunities. Intelligibility and grammar are not considered in BLEU's evaluation.

The F-score, or F-measure, is a metric in binary classification and information retrieval systems that combines precision and recall. Precision is the number of true positives divided by all samples predicted positive, while recall is the number of true positives divided by all actual positives. The F1 score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall, providing a balanced metric. The more generic F𝛽 score applies weights to precision and recall based on importance. An F-score of 1.0 indicates perfect precision and recall, while a

METEOR is a metric for evaluating machine translation based on the harmonic mean of unigram precision and recall, with recall weighted higher. It includes features like stemming and synonymy matching, in addition to exact word matching. Designed to address issues with BLEU, it aims for better correlation with human judgement at the sentence level. Results show up to 0.964 correlation at the corpus level compared to BLEU's 0.817. content: NIST, based on BLEU, evaluates text quality in machine translation. It considers not only n-gram precision but also the informativeness of each n-gram. For instance, rare n-grams receive more weight. This differs from BLEU as it does not heavily penalize small translation length variations.

P4 metric is a performance evaluation tool for binary classifiers, calculated from precision, recall, specificity, and NPV. Similar to F1 metric but addressing criticisms, it can be seen as an extension. Like other met

Post-editing involves humans amending machine-generated translations to achieve an acceptable final product. A person who does this is called a post-editor. It is linked to pre-editing, where the source text is edited before machine translation. Post-editing corrects mistakes and ensures quality as agreed upon by the client. Light post-editing makes the text understandable, while full post-editing also focuses on style. With improvements in machine translation, full post-editing is becoming an alternative to manual translation. CAT tools support post-editing of machine translated output.

While WER is useful for system comparison and evaluation, it lacks details on translation errors. Dynamic string alignment helps align sequences, and the power law theory explores the relationship between perplexity and WER. Further research is nee

Users prefer learning by doing tasks rather than studying manuals, making this method valuable for early design phases. It provides quick results at a lower

Checkmarx is a US-based enterprise security company founded in 2006. They offer AST solutions to integrate security in all stages of SDLC, known as "shift everywhere."

Code coverage is a measure of the proportion of source code that is executed when running a test suite in software engineering. High test coverage indicates lower chances of undetected bugs. Various metrics can be used, such as the percentage of subroutines and statements executed. It was one of the first systematic testing methods, first mentioned in a 1963 article in Communications of the ACM by

Debug_new is a technique in C++ that involves overloading operator new and delete to debug memory usage by intercepting allocation and deallocation calls. It uses a macro named DEBUG_NEW to record file/line information. This method is used in Microsoft Visual C++. While it has limitations, such as not catching memory leaks by C functions like malloc, it is simple to use and fast compared to other memory debugger solutions. T

content: Fuzzing is an automated software testing technique where invalid or random data is inputted into a program to monitor for exceptions. It is used to test programs with structured inputs, generating semi-valid inputs that can expose unexpected behaviors. Fuzzing is especially useful for testing code that handles inputs crossing trust boundaries for security purposes, prioritizing critical areas over less vulnerable ones.

A penetration test, also known as a pentest, is an authorized simulated cyberattack to evaluate a system's security, not to be confused with a vulnerability assessment. It aims to identify weaknesses and strengths, enabling a full risk assessment. The process involves setting goals, gathering information, and using various means to attain those goals, with different levels of information sharing between the auditor and target system. The test helps identify vulnerabilities and estimate the system's overall security. Security issues uncovered are reported to the system owner, along with potential impacts and suggested countermeasures.

The UK National Cyber Security Center defines penetration testing as a method to assess system security by attempting to breach it using tools and techniques that adversaries might use. The primary goal of a penetration test is to find vulnerabilities that could be exploited by malicious actors and recommend mitigation strategies to the client. It is a component of a full security audit and is required for compliance with standards like the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard and NIST Risk Management Framework.

Various frameworks and methodologies exist for conducting penetration tests, such as the OSSTMM, PTES, NIST SP 800-115, ISSAF, and OWASP Testing Guide. CREST provides industry guidance for penetration tests with its Defensible Penetration Test standard. Flaw hypothesis methodology is a technique for predicting and prioritizing potential flaws in a software system before testing it.

Different types of penetration testing include Network (external and internal), Wireless, Web Application, Social Engineering, and Remediation Verification, based on the organization's goals.

Security testing is essential for detecting flaws in information systems and ensuring data protection and functionality. Passing security testing does not guarantee a system is flaw-free or meets all security requirements. Common requirements include confidentiality, integrity, authentication, availability, authorization, and non-repudiation. The specific requirements tested vary based on the system. Security testing can be done in various way

content: Static application security testing (SAST) reviews source code to identify vulnerabilities. Unlike dynamic testing tools, SAST focuses on code content, detecting 50% of vulnerabilities. It is used early in the SDLC and for quality assurance, despite false positives. Integrated into development, SAST reduces downtime and protects private data. In 2018, over 612 million records were hacked, highlighting the importance of SAST in securing software.

Dynamic application security testing (DAST) is a non-functional testing process that identifies security weaknesses in an application. It can be done manually or using automated tools. Manual assessment involves human intervention to catch flaws missed by automated tools, such as business logic errors and zero-day vulnerabilities. In contrast, DAST tools communicate with a web application to pinpoint vulnerabilities and weaknesses without access to the source code. They perform black-box tests, detecting vulnerabilities in query strings, headers, verbs (GET/POST/PUT), and DOM injection. Once configured, DAST tools can

The Graph500 rates supercomputer systems based on data-intensive loads, aiming to raise awareness of complex data problems. The project started in 2010 and new lists are published biannually, ranking systems by GTEPS. The rating includes hundreds of systems, with 174 as of June 2014. The winning algorithm and implementation are detailed in a paper titled "Extreme scale breadth-first search on supercomputers." The Green Graph 500 list ranks systems by performance per Watt, similar to the Green 500 for TOP500.
HPC Challenge Benchmark tests multiple attributes in HPC system performance. Co-sponsored by DARPA, US DOE, and NSF, project combines benchmarks to evaluate high-pe

The High Performance Conjugate Gradients Benchmark, proposed by researchers from Sandia National Laboratories and the University of Tennessee, models real-world data access patterns for supercomputers. It tests the impact of memory subsystem limitations on computing performance, achieving only a fraction of peak FLOPS due to being internally I/O bound. HPCG complements LINPACK benchmarks by stressing internal interconnects. Summit, Sierra, and K computer held top spots in HPCG rankings in 2018, with Fugaku surpassing Summit in 2020. Summit now ranks 4th, with LUMI 3rd, and Frontier 2nd. The HPCG benchmark s

content: The LINPACK Benchmarks measure a system's floating-point computing power by solving linear equations. Developed by Jack Dongarra, they are used to rank the world's most powerful supercomputers in the TOP500 list. While the benchmarks provide a good estimate of a computer's performance, actual performance may vary due to various factors. The benchmarks are based on the number of floating-point operations a computer can perform per second, known as FLOPS. The benchmarks are named after the LINPACK package, a collection of algebra Fortran subroutines from the 1980s, which has since been replaced by other libraries.

The TOP500 project ranks the 500 most powerful non-distributed computer systems globally. Started in 1993, updates are released twice a year at key conferences. Rankings are based on HPL benchmarks, tracking trends in high-performance computing. The 60th TOP500, from November 2022, highlights the US's Frontier as the most powerful, with 1102 petaFlops. As of 2023, the US leads with 161 supercomputers, followed by China with 104. The list is compiled by Jack Dongarra, Erich Strohmaier, and Horst Simon. Other lists within the project include Green500 and HPCG, measuring energy efficiency and I/O bandwidth, respectively.

3DMark by UL is a benchmarking tool for measuring a computer's 3D graphics and CPU processing performance. It produces a score to compare hardware configurations, favored by gamers and overclockers. Since 1998, various versions have been released, with scores not comparable across versions due to changes in DirectX API. Older versions like 3DMark 11 are now available for free on UL's website.

Accelerated aging tests use harsh conditions like heat, humidity, and vibration to speed up the aging process of items in a controlled laboratory setting. This helps predict the long-term effects of stress on a product when lifespan data is unavailable. For new products like car engines or polymers, this is especially useful. Physical and chemical tests are carried out by subjecting the product to prolonged stress, extreme stress to speed up aging, or intentional stress to force failures for analysis. Environmental chambers are used for testing, along with rapid changes in temperature, humidity, pressure, and strain to simulate real-world conditions.

content: Blinded wine tasting involves tasters being unaware of the wines' identities, commonly used by wine professionals to ensure impartiality in competitions and certifications. Scientists also use this method to study the human olfactory system and the ability to identify various compounds contributing to wine aroma. Economists use blinded tastings to test hypotheses related to the wine market. Some trials suggest people struggle to distinguish between ordinary and expensive wines based on aroma and taste. Academic research questions the consistency of professional tasters' judgment.

Cannabis product testing is crucial in ensuring the quality and safety of products in the emerging consumer market. Labs analyze cannabinoids, terpenes, contaminants like mold and pesticides, and potency levels. The popularity of cannabis products has skyrocketed since legalization in the US in 2012, with many states legalizing recreational and medical use. However, limited regulation poses risks to consumer safety, with many startups avoiding costly testing. Advanced analytical testing is essential to guarantee the quality and safety of cannabis products before they are sold to consumers.

Coffee cupping is the practice of tasting and smelling brewed coffee, typically done by professionals known as "Q Graders". It involves deeply sniffing the coffee and slurping it from a spoon to detect aspects like body, sweetness, acidity, flavor, and aftertaste. By identifying the unique flavors from the region where the beans were grown, cuppers can determine the coffee's origin.

content: Commercialization is the process of bringing a new product or production method to market. It often involves moving from research and development to mass market availability. This transition requires time and money to engineer industrial systems for commercial use. The final stage includes advertising and marketing efforts to encourage early adoption. Technologies can then move towards consumer goods, such as computers moving from the laboratory to the home or body.

content: Compressive strength is a material's ability to withstand loads pushing it together, unlike tensile strength which resists being pulled apart. Materials may fracture or deform irreversibly at their compressive strength limit. This value is crucial in designing structures and is often measured using a universal testing machine, with results varying based on testing method and conditions. Compressive strength values are typically reported in relation to technical standards.

content: Conformance testing is a crucial part of ensuring that processes, products, or services meet the requirements of a standard, contract, or regulation. It can involve logical or physical testing, as well as criteria like mathematics or chemistry. Beyond simply checking for conformance, testing may also assess efficiency, interoperability, or other aspects. Certification from accredited organizations can demonstrate compliance with technical standards, boosting confidence for manufacturers, suppliers, and end users. Certification allows products or services to be marketed as certif
A crash test is destructive testing to ensure safe design standards in crashworthiness for transportation modes or relate

Flight testing in aeronautical engineering develops equipment to test aircraft behavior and systems, or launch vehicle and spacecraft phases. Instrumentation systems with proprietary transducers and data acquisition are used to sample and analyze data during flights for accuracy. The flight test phase identifies and corrects design issues, verifies vehicle capabilities, and may last from weeks to years depending on the project's complexity.

content: Nondestructive testing (NDT) is a valuable technique used in various industries to evaluate materials without causing damage. Common methods include eddy-current, magnetic-particle, liquid penetrant, radiographic, ultrasonic, and visual testing. NDT is used in fields such as engineering, medicine, and art, and has had significant impacts on medical imaging. NDT training is essential for personnel conducting these examinations, which rely on electromagnetic radiation, sound, and signal conversions to assess articles for integrity and composition. Methods include visual inspection, radiographic testing, ultrasonic testing, and liquid penetrant testing. High-speed cameras can also be used to analyze and document nondestructive failure modes.

Tests can be qualitative or quantitative, with physical tests being common. Chemical tests are also conducted for food and pharmaceutical packaging. Testing varies from simple to extensive designs, covering aspects like recyclability and degradation in different environments.

content: Sensometrics is a interdisciplinary scientific discipline that applies mathematical, statistical, and computational methods to Sensory and Consumer Science. It involves everything from designing experiments to analyzing perceptions and preferences. Sensometrics is crucial for product development, quality assurance, market research, and understanding consumer behavior.

Sensory analysis is a scientific approach that uses human senses to evaluate consumer products. It involves panels of assessors testing products and recording their responses for statistical analysis. Large companies often have dedicated sensory analysis departments. The discipline is divided into analytical testing (objective facts), affective testing (subjective preferences), and perception (biochemical and psychological aspect

A standards organization, also known as a standards body or SDO, develops and promotes technical standards to ensure uniformity across industries. These standards help products work together seamlessly, like ensuring compatibility between different brands of devices. While most standards are voluntary, some become mandatory for safety or consumer protection reasons. Formal standards are approved by a standards organization, while de facto standards gain widespread acceptance without formal approval. Examples include Hayes command set and Apple's TrueType font design. The term standards organization does not refer to individual participants within the organization.

Surveys are used in public opinion polls, healthcare studies, market research, government surveys, and censuses. While censuses do not involve sampling, they still use survey methods like questionnaires and follow-up techniques. content: Usability testing is a vital technique in user-centered design, evaluating products by testing them on real users to assess their intuitive design. It is crucial for the success of a product, as user confusion can lead to quick obsolescence. This method contrasts with expert evaluations, focusing on how well a product meets its intended purposes. Common subjects for usability testing include food, consumer products, websites, computer interfaces, documents, and devices. It measures the ease of use of specific objects, while general human-computer interaction st

content: Verification and validation (V&V) are crucial aspects of quality management systems like ISO 9000. They ensure that a product meets requirements and functions as intended. These processes can be performed independently by a neutral third party, known as IV&V. Definitions of verification and validation can vary, with some using the terms interchangeably. The PMBOK guide defines validation as meeting customer needs, while verification is assessing compliance with regulations or requirements. Validation typically involves external stakeholders, while verification is often an internal process.

content: The Charpy impact test is a high strain rate test used to determine the energy absorbed by a material during fracture, indicating its notch toughness. Widely used in industry for its ease and cost-efficiency, the test was crucial during World War II for understanding ship fracture problems. Developed by S. B. Russell and Georges Charpy in the early 1900s, it is also known as the Charpy V-n

The four-point flexural test measures modulus of elasticity in bending, flexural stress, flexural strain, and stress-strain response of a material. It is similar to three-point bending, but with a fourth bearing putting more of the beam under stress. This is crucial for studying brittle materials, where flaws exposed to stress impact strength and crack initiation. Unlike three-point bending, four-point bending eliminates shear forces between loading pins, making it ideal for brittle materials. It is commonly used to assess fatigue and stiffness in asphalt mixtures.
